quotes.topic_title: AI, org flattening, and managers as ICs
quotes.text: It used to be, okay, I don't have the skills to do 10 different jobs, but now with AI allows me to do many of those jobs myself. We need to dissolve the boundaries of these traditional roles and call ourselves builders. I'd love for us to get to the world where that's the title.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: A practical reframing for how individuals and teams should redefine roles and operate in an AI-enabled, more generalist world.

quotes.topic_title: AI, org flattening, and managers as ICs
quotes.text: Management is still really critical. You have a north star, you have a vision, and you're just trying to figure out how to use the resources that you have to get that thing done. Used to be people, but now it's basically models and different models have different strengths. You have to assemble the Avengers so that you can use the right tools for the right purposes.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: A memorable framework for modern management as orchestrating the right mix of AI tools/models toward a clear vision.

quotes.topic_title: AI, org flattening, and managers as ICs
quotes.text: It's always been manager's job to manage change. I just think the rate of change is accelerating. Today management is really about this idea of be sturdy while being flexible. So I think about this metaphor a lot of the willow tree. It can survive a lot of storms, disasters, et cetera, but it's also very flexible.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: A concrete mental model for leadership under volatility: resilience without rigidity.

quotes.topic_title: AI, org flattening, and managers as ICs
quotes.text: You want to diagnose with data and treat with design. Data is not a tool that's going to tell you what you should build. I don't actually think a lot of the fast growing companies are using data well at this point. Traditionally things just didn't grow that fast. These companies are totally getting by on just good instincts and good vibes, but what always happens is eventually things stop growing.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: Actionable guidance on how to use data correctly (diagnosis) while challenging the assumption that fast growth implies strong analytics discipline.

quotes.topic_title: Managing change: the willow tree metaphor
quotes.text: It's always been manager's job to manage change. I just think the rate of change is accelerating.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: Reframes management as fundamentally about change, with urgency driven by today’s faster pace of shifts.

quotes.topic_title: Managing change: the willow tree metaphor
quotes.text: Today management is really about this idea of be sturdy while being flexible.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: Offers a practical guiding principle for leaders navigating uncertainty: balance stability with adaptability.

quotes.topic_title: Managing change: the willow tree metaphor
quotes.text: So I think about this metaphor a lot of the willow tree. It can survive a lot of storms, disasters, et cetera, but it's also very flexible.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: Introduces a memorable mental model for resilience: enduring disruption by bending rather than breaking.

quotes.topic_title: Diagnose with data, treat with design
quotes.text: You want to diagnose with data and treat with design.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: A crisp framework for separating problem discovery (data) from solution creation (design).

quotes.topic_title: Diagnose with data, treat with design
quotes.text: Data is not a tool that's going to tell you what you should build.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reminder that analytics informs decisions but doesn’t replace product judgment and design work.

quotes.topic_title: Diagnose with data, treat with design
quotes.text: I don't actually think a lot of the fast growing companies are using data well at this point.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: Highlights a common blind spot: rapid growth can mask weak measurement and decision systems.

quotes.topic_title: Diagnose with data, treat with design
quotes.text: These companies are totally getting by on just good instincts and good vibes, but what always happens is eventually things stop growing.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: Actionable warning that intuition-driven execution eventually hits limits, forcing better instrumentation and data discipline.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Having worked at a mega large corp like Meta as head of design and now as a founder at a tiny startup that's all about using data to help you make decisions, it's really rare for someone to have this spectrum of experiences.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights the value of combining big-company and startup experience, especially around decision-making with data.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In our conversation, we talk about how learning to be a great manager directly translates to learning how to use AI tools extremely well, which specific skills will become more valuable in the next couple of years, her most valuable and timeless advice for new managers, why she's not hiring product managers at her startup, her simple heuristic for knowing when to use data and when to use intuition in making decisions.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Previews several actionable themes, including a decision heuristic for data vs. intuition and a contrarian hiring stance on PMs.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: If you become an annual subscriber of my newsletter, you get 15 incredible products for free for an entire year, including Lovable, Replit, Bolt, n8n, Linear, Superhuman, Descript, Whisperflow, Gamma, Perplexity, Warp, Granola, Magic Patterns, ChatPRD and Mobbin.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A concrete, specific example list (15 tools) that practitioners can explore to upgrade their workflow.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Where most traditional banking websites and apps are clunky and hard to use, Mercury is meticulously designed to be an intuitive and simple experience.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a practical product-selection heuristic: prioritize tools that reduce operational friction through strong UX.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: And Mercury brings all the ways that you use money into a single product, including credit cards, invoicing, bill pay, reimbursements for your teammates and capital.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Suggests an operational consolidation model—centralize financial workflows to simplify management and visibility.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: To thrive in the AI era, organizations need to adapt quickly, but many organization leaders struggle to answer pressing questions like which tools are working, how are they being used, what's actually driving value?
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Frames a measurement-first approach to AI adoption: focus on usage and value drivers rather than hype or tool count.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: See what over 200,000 entrepreneurs love about Mercury.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Provides a concrete adoption data point that can be used as a credibility signal when evaluating vendors.

quotes.topic_title: Reunion, podcast growth, and the fireplace Easter egg
quotes.text: So funny enough, I don't know how many people have noticed this Easter egg that I've stuck with, in that first studio, I was just watching the episode, I had this funny little mirror. I don't know if I had in the first episode with a fireplace that was showing up in that mirror because the mirror was showing something stupid. And so I've just kind of kept this fireplace across every studio I've moved across in my various places.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A memorable example of using a consistent, intentional “Easter egg” as a repeatable branding/continuity device across changing setups.

quotes.topic_title: Reunion, podcast growth, and the fireplace Easter egg
quotes.text: I even remember we chatted. Video was kind of a newer thing. You're like, "We'll record it, but it's really about the audio." And now we moved into the video era.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: Highlights a practical shift in distribution strategy over time—starting audio-first, then adapting as audience consumption changes.

quotes.topic_title: Reunion, podcast growth, and the fireplace Easter egg
quotes.text: That's the idea. I was actually just looking at the stats. So since that first episode, this podcast has done over 20 million downloads. It's approaching 30 million downloads.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A concrete growth data point that signals the scale possible from compounding audience-building over multiple years.

quotes.topic_title: Reunion, podcast growth, and the fireplace Easter egg
quotes.text: It's really incredible. I think it is a testament to just your curiosity and how much you really care about the craft of building great products and sharing that with the world.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: Points to a replicable driver of long-term content success: sustained curiosity and craft focus as a differentiator.

quotes.topic_title: Re-releasing The Making of a Manager
quotes.text: My big motivation to write it was I think largely because I felt if I had to write this thing, I was likely going to become a better manager.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: A practical self-improvement method: use writing/teaching as a forcing function to level up your own management skills.

quotes.topic_title: Re-releasing The Making of a Manager
quotes.text: And I know that part of my process is when I really sit down to try and put down everything I feel and write letters to myself, it really helps me.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: A concrete reflective practice (writing letters to yourself) that can help managers clarify thinking and improve decision-making.

quotes.topic_title: Re-releasing The Making of a Manager
quotes.text: I couldn't have expected that it would have much wider reach than that and that's been really awesome.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: A counterintuitive lesson about impact: writing for a narrow audience can unexpectedly resonate far beyond it.

quotes.topic_title: Re-releasing The Making of a Manager
quotes.text: I thought I was the only one who felt this way, but this book made me realize that, hey, these are very normal feelings.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: Highlights the value of normalizing common (often hidden) struggles like uncertainty and imposter feelings in management.

quotes.topic_title: Re-releasing The Making of a Manager
quotes.text: That's certainly how I felt, just stumbling through and feeling like an imposter for so many years.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: A memorable, relatable framing that challenges the assumption that good managers feel confident early on.

quotes.topic_title: Everyone becomes a manager of AI agents
quotes.text: management is just about, in my mind, having an outcome.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: A simple, portable definition of management that maps cleanly from people to AI agents.

quotes.topic_title: Everyone becomes a manager of AI agents
quotes.text: You still need a goal. You need to be very clear about what the outcome is and you have to understand the strengths of, used to be people, but now it's basically models.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: A practical mental model for “managing agents” as goal clarity plus matching tasks to model strengths.

quotes.topic_title: Everyone becomes a manager of AI agents
quotes.text: I think it's still very important for us to be able to provide the right context, provide the right high level instruction so that we get what we want.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: Actionable guidance on where humans still add leverage even as agents get more capable.

quotes.topic_title: Everyone becomes a manager of AI agents
quotes.text: The first is defining the goal and defining the outcome and being really, really crystal clear on what does success look like.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: A concrete skill to double down on for both people management and effective agent prompting.

quotes.topic_title: Everyone becomes a manager of AI agents
quotes.text: So figuring out how to boil it down so that an agent can really understand what success and failure looks like is a lot of the game.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reframing: the hard part isn’t “prompting,” it’s specifying success/failure precisely.

quotes.topic_title: Builders, smaller teams, and no-PM experiments
quotes.text: So the main thing that I felt so excited about, and this is something I tell my team all the time, is we need to dissolve the boundaries of these traditional roles.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: A clear operating principle for designing teams in an AI-enabled world: optimize around outcomes/skills, not rigid role lanes.

quotes.topic_title: Builders, smaller teams, and no-PM experiments
quotes.text: So in some ways we can drop all of these different role distinctions and call ourselves builders.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: A memorable reframing that encourages cross-functional ownership and reduces handoffs by treating everyone as a general-purpose creator.

quotes.topic_title: Builders, smaller teams, and no-PM experiments
quotes.text: I find that sometimes when you have a designer or a product manager, and let's say I'm an engineer, then when I have a problem, like I need to figure out the product definition, my default will be, well, I've got these people and that's kind of their job description, so I'm just going to delegate that to them.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: Counterintuitive diagnosis: adding specialized roles can unintentionally reduce product thinking and ownership among engineers.

quotes.topic_title: Builders, smaller teams, and no-PM experiments
quotes.text: And so we found that if we actually make teams smaller and we even in the past, pre-AI, just have fewer of these, it allowed everyone to be like, "Wait, we don't have product manager on the team, so communication's up to me. Figuring out how we get greatest value to users is something that is now strictly in my charter."
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: A practical team-design lever (smaller teams, fewer roles) that forces end-to-end ownership and speeds up decision-making.

quotes.topic_title: Builders, smaller teams, and no-PM experiments
quotes.text: But I like to think of it as what are the skills that are needed for this and can we now find a couple people?
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: A skills-first staffing methodology: start from required capabilities, then assemble a minimal team rather than following a standard PM/design/eng template.

quotes.topic_title: AI tools accelerating work and learning
quotes.text: And in fact, I think these days ChatGPT or these other AI tools are better teachers.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: Challenges the default assumption that humans are the best way to learn new domains at work, positioning AI as a superior on-demand teacher.

quotes.topic_title: AI tools accelerating work and learning
quotes.text: Sometimes what I'll do is I'll find a curriculum online. And if you take a course, it'll be like this 12 week curriculum and I'll just feed it into ChatGPT and I'll say, "Help me customize a program for me using the ways that I like to learn."
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: A practical method for turning generic learning resources into a personalized training plan tailored to your learning style.

quotes.topic_title: AI tools accelerating work and learning
quotes.text: We're different types of learners and so the idea of a tool that personalizes learning for each of us really helps us, I think, accelerate and just learn these skills much faster than before.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: Frames AI as a scalable personalization layer for upskilling across a team, increasing learning speed by matching individual preferences.

quotes.topic_title: AI tools accelerating work and learning
quotes.text: But it helps so much because it's interactive and so we can really test whether we really understand the concept by trying to retell it back in our own way.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: Introduces an actionable “teach-back” loop with AI as a critique partner to validate and deepen understanding.

quotes.topic_title: AI tools accelerating work and learning
quotes.text: Julie, I feel like I really understand the how. I know the algorithms, I know we do root cause analysis, how we do that. But what I don't really understand is why or when this would be most useful. In what context in a company would this company come up?
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: A concrete example of a common skills gap (how vs. when/why) that AI can help close by providing business context to technical practitioners.

quotes.topic_title: Why fast-growing AI companies underuse data
quotes.text: I don't actually think a lot of the fast-growing companies are using data well at this point.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: Contrarian take that hypergrowth often masks weak data practices, challenging the assumption that top AI companies are data-driven.

quotes.topic_title: Why fast-growing AI companies underuse data
quotes.text: And so today we see companies that are growing insane and there's still about 10 people or two people or however many people, but they've got hundreds of millions in ARR and hundreds of millions of users.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: Concrete example illustrating how scale can outpace headcount and infrastructure, creating a data/observability gap.

quotes.topic_title: Why fast-growing AI companies underuse data
quotes.text: So I would say that these companies are totally getting by on just good instincts and good vibes and we see that.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: Memorable diagnosis of how teams operate without instrumentation—useful for practitioners to recognize when they’re “flying blind.”

quotes.topic_title: Why fast-growing AI companies underuse data
quotes.text: And then you start to be able to see the power of, if you've instrumented everything very well and you have a very good observability model for your business, it's much easier to start to get into the root cause, it's easier to even predict whether growth will slow down at a certain point, it's easier to catch these trends earlier.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: Actionable framework: invest in instrumentation + an “observability model” to enable root-cause analysis and earlier detection of growth slowdowns.

quotes.topic_title: Why fast-growing AI companies underuse data
quotes.text: Conversational analytics is totally different.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: Signals a methodology shift practitioners must make when moving from click-based products to LLM/conversational UX.

quotes.topic_title: Designers vs data: misconceptions and balance
quotes.text: what you really want is you want to diagnose with data and treat with design.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: A crisp framework for balancing analytics and craft: use data to find/locate problems, then use design to create solutions.

quotes.topic_title: Designers vs data: misconceptions and balance
quotes.text: It just gives you a story that better reflects reality.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: Reframes data as a reality-check against internal narratives rather than a decision-making replacement.

quotes.topic_title: Designers vs data: misconceptions and balance
quotes.text: To me data is also, well, what did people put onto TikTok and which things went viral, and what are they saying in the Twitter verse or X verse I guess is what it's called now.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: Expands “data” beyond dashboards to include qualitative, real-world signals practitioners can actively monitor.

quotes.topic_title: Designers vs data: misconceptions and balance
quotes.text: the fact that you still have to choose which things you look at, is an art, not a science.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: Highlights that metric selection is a judgment call—an often-missed source of bias and leverage in “data-driven” work.

quotes.topic_title: Designers vs data: misconceptions and balance
quotes.text: you just actually can't make a really great product by thinking you can A-B test your way into it.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: A counterintuitive warning against over-relying on experimentation as a substitute for vision and creative problem-solving.

quotes.topic_title: AI-era management: uncertainty, fear, and communication
quotes.text: So I think today, management is really about this idea of be sturdy while being flexible, and that is a very hard thing to pull off, but I think that's at least when I even go into... I'm like, "Be like the willow tree, Julie. Just imagine the willow tree and try and channel that as the kind of feeling of what it is that we're trying to do together."
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for leading teams through AI-driven volatility: resilience comes from flexibility, not rigidity.

quotes.topic_title: AI-era management: uncertainty, fear, and communication
quotes.text: And so I find that there's just a great deal more uncertainty that people have about things, like where is AI going to be in two years from now? I don't know. Who really knows?
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: Highlights the core management challenge in the AI era: planning and morale must operate under genuine uncertainty rather than predictable roadmaps.

quotes.topic_title: AI-era management: uncertainty, fear, and communication
quotes.text: And so I think that the skills that become more important are obviously communication, feedback, compassion, but just being able to work with humans and to have them understand that yes, we are in a state of change.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: Actionable guidance on what to double down on as a manager when tools and roles shift quickly: human-centered communication and support.

quotes.topic_title: AI-era management: uncertainty, fear, and communication
quotes.text: I think if you don't think it's good, it's kind of a painful way to live.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: A reframing tactic for sustained change: treating disruption as inherently negative makes adaptation emotionally unsustainable.

quotes.topic_title: AI-era management: uncertainty, fear, and communication
quotes.text: And I think if managers who try to pretend like it isn't there, it's all good, no one's upset, et cetera, there's something also missing about just addressing and being able to be like, yeah, it's hard. Change is hard.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: Practical advice for change leadership: acknowledge fear and difficulty explicitly rather than forcing optimism, to prevent teams from spiraling.

quotes.topic_title: Timeless advice: manage yourself and dimensionality
quotes.text: The first thing that comes to mind is the importance of managing yourself and understanding yourself.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: Puts self-management as the foundational skill for new managers before any tactics or team management.

quotes.topic_title: Timeless advice: manage yourself and dimensionality
quotes.text: And I am a very big believer that every strength is its own weakness, and every weakness is a strength.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: A counterintuitive lens for interpreting strengths/weaknesses that encourages balanced self-awareness and tradeoff thinking.

quotes.topic_title: Timeless advice: manage yourself and dimensionality
quotes.text: So what dimensionality means is you're a human being, but we can kind of look at you in infinite dimensions.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: Introduces “dimensionality” as a mental model for evaluating performance and feedback without overgeneralizing to identity.

quotes.topic_title: Timeless advice: manage yourself and dimensionality
quotes.text: And ideally you're not like, "Julie is saying I'm a bad person, my identity is at risk," right? Because it's just one dimension of who you are.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: Shows how to receive feedback more objectively by separating critique of a skill dimension from personal worth.

quotes.topic_title: Timeless advice: manage yourself and dimensionality
quotes.text: somebody can give you feedback or you can be maybe not great at certain dimensions, you can have room to improve, and that's not who you are because you are all of these infinite dimensions in one, and none of them is representative of your true worth as an individual.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: A memorable reframing that helps managers and ICs depersonalize feedback and focus on growth across dimensions.
